Most han had gunnery instructors, villages=
 were licensed to use firearms to 
scare off or kill threatening animals, a=
nd guns were a necessity in various 
locations due to intrusions from Russi=
ans in the far North and defense of ports 
in the South.  To put it simply =
- there were no active wars, so technological 
advancement of guns in Japan=
 wasn't necessary, but guns weren't thrown away. 
The book "Giving Up the G=
un" by Perrin is a joke, and has been ridiculed and 
lambasted in the Weste=
rn and Japanese scholarship for decades, but his book is

use non-Japanese history experts still quote it.
